title: Gnome Tweaks Scaling Factor garbles OBS interface in 26.1

labels.name: Confirmed
labels.description: This bug report has been confirmed by project members

body:
<!-- READ THIS FIRST -->
<!-- The OBS Studio GitHub issue tracker is **ONLY** to be -->
<!-- used for reporting Bugs that have replication steps. -->

<!-- You can post Feature Requests here: https://ideas.obsproject.com/ -->
<!-- Get help for Support Issues here: https://obsproject.com/help -->

<!--- Provide a general summary of the issue in the Title above -->

## Platform
<!-- Please fill out the following information about your bug report. -->
<!-- If you are on Linux and installed using a package, please list the package type. -->
Operating system and version: Arch Linux (5.10.4-arch2-1)
OBS Studio version: 26.1.0-2

## Expected Behavior
<!--- Tell us what should happen -->
OBS interface should look normal when font scaling is applied in Gnome Tweaks
![https://i.imgur.com/nti37zC.png](https://i.imgur.com/nti37zC.png)

## Current Behavior
<!--- Tell us what happens instead of the expected behavior. -->
<!--- Please include a log file here if possible. -->
OBS interface is completely garbled when font scaling is applied in Gnome Tweaks
![https://i.imgur.com/p8kpuK5.png](https://i.imgur.com/p8kpuK5.png)

When going from windowed to maximized makes it worse: ![https://i.imgur.com/7v9QPBx.png](https://i.imgur.com/7v9QPBx.png)

## Steps to Reproduce
<!--- Provide a link to a live example, or an unambiguous set of steps to -->
<!--- reproduce this bug. Include code to reproduce, if relevant. -->
<!--- Screenshots and video are encouraged if applicable. -->
1. Open Gnome Tweaks and go to the Fonts tab
2. Set the Scaling Factor to 0.90 ![https://i.imgur.com/oVBaSuu.png](https://i.imgur.com/oVBaSuu.png)
3. Open OBS
4. Interface unusable
5. In Tweaks, set Scaling Factor to 1 ![https://i.imgur.com/lH3TGrS.png](https://i.imgur.com/lH3TGrS.png)
6. OBS looks normal

## Additional information
<!--- Not obligatory, but provide any additional details or information -->
<!--- that you feel might be relevant to the issue -->
This issue was not present in version 25.x, as I always had the Scaling Factor set to 0.90. KeepassXC had a similar problem earlier this year: https://github.com/keepassxreboot/keepassxc/issues/5029
